basics.name: Aidan Acquah
basics.label: Data Analyst & Software Engineer
basics.summary: An experienced data analyst and software engineer with a unique blend of academic rigour and practical knowledge. Specialized in health data science, developing machine learning models and data-driven insights.

work.name: University of Oxford
work.summary: Developed and maintained open-source pip packages and GitHub repositories. Adapted and ran unit and system testing for updates. Contributed to OxWearables packages licensed for commercial use.
highlights: Conducted unit testing on pip packages

work.name: GSK plc
work.summary: Conducted advanced analyses of health data using machine learning models. Collaborated internationally for novel digital biomarker discovery.
highlights: Applied machine learning to health data

work.name: University of Oxford
work.summary: Delivered lab sessions in R, Python, and C++ to undergraduate and master's students, focusing on data analysis and machine learning concepts.
highlights: Taught programming and data science concepts
Hands-on teaching in Python, R, and C++

work.name: Tessella Ltd
work.summary: Developed and tested software for large clients, including BP, Rolls Royce, and Unilever. Applied various programming languages and machine learning tools in data-intensive environments.
highlights: Worked with BP, Rolls Royce, and Unilever

courses: Advanced data science and machine learning techniques
Applied statistical analyses using Cox regression

publications.name: Daily steps are a predictor of, but perhaps not a modifiable risk factor for Parkinson's Disease: findings from the UK Biobank.
Walking recognition in Parkinson's disease populations using wrist-worn accelerometers.

projects.name: actinet
projects.summary: pip package for activity data analysis using wearable sensors.

projects.name: PD walking
projects.summary: Detecting walking using wrist-worn accelerometer in healthy and Parkinson's disease individuals.

projects.name: PD risk analysis
projects.summary: Observing how wrist-worn accelerometers can improve risk models for incident Parkinson's disease.
